results.content:
The instructor is obviously very knowledgable. I left an average review because I don't feel this is really a "course" per se. I would call it instead a code walk-through. He pastes in the source of a plugin he has previously written function by function and then very quickly walks through the code line-by-line, briefly describing each command's purpose. 

From this format I was able to glean some new knowledge, but not a whole lot. Its benefit to me was largely demonstrating that a few features of wordpress APIs existed that I didn't previously know about.  Also having access to the well-commented final plugin code is valuable for sure, since I will be able to refer to it in the future. 

I simply prefer it when instructors are actually coding their examples on screen, in real time, so you can get the benefit of seeing their thought processes, the evolution of the code, and see the function of their app/site unfold incrementally. 

Short of that, I might have appreciated if at the beginning of a given section he would demonstrate the functionality he was about to explain. There were many times when I was lost about what X or Y function was trying to achieve, and this could have been helped if he showed the site _doing_ the thing he was about to start explaining. Since he evidently had the final code during the time of recording.

response.content:

As this was my first course some changes were made while recording the course in order to speed up the learning process and avoid mistakes. Since most students don't have the time to watch me code every single line I decided to copy and paste portions of my code throughout the course to save time and avoid typos. I've learned so many ways to improve future courses since launching this one and appreciate everyone's feedback. The overwhelming majority of my students have enjoyed this course and experienced a lot of value from it. I would love to offer you a full refund should you like to find a course better suited for your learning style.

results.content:
I thought I would learn with an advanced plugin development course. I didn't.
This course actually demonstrates horrible practises you should avoid as a plugin developer:
 - Misuse of escaping and sanitizing functions.
 - Security issues (permissions? nonces ?)
 - Hardcoded text strings : the plugin cannot be translated.
 - Reliance on thirdparty plugin like ACF and CPTUI.
 - Including the whole ACF plugin in a subfolder of the plugin being developped (WHAT ?!?)
 - Harcoded ACF key in a function (WHAT ?!?)
 - Absolute reliance on Javascript to process a simple form.
 - Using jquery to add/hide admin menu items.
 - A single plugin file. Highly difficult to read through.
 - Bad handling of query strings.
 - Partial use of the settings API.
... and much more.

I'm sure I'll find out more in the rest of the course, but so far, that's a pretty big list of awful practises.

I'm really sorry to say that, but please don't buy this course. The author doesn't know WordPress enough and doesn't leverage what it has to offer.

response.content:
Hi Dubroeucq,

Thanks for your thoughtful review of this course. I'm sorry that you expected an advanced plugin development course and got something else. This course was deliberately designed to help as many people at different experience levels get their feet wet in plugin development and as you've pointed out is not an exhaustive teaching of every aspect of plugin development. The course description includes a disclaimer about the use of third-party plugins in this course to speed up development, perhaps you missed this when you initially signed up. 

I'd be the first to admit that there are many areas this course could be improved and as my first ever online course I have been keeping account of my student suggestions on how I can improve my teaching, style and structure in future lectures and courses and your comments will be added to that list.

I understand that not everyone is going to experience my course in the same way, but with an average of 4.5 star rating on this course, I would have to assume that the majority of my 4000+ students find a lot of value here. All that said, let me know and I'd be happy to offer you a full refund.

Happy coding friend,

Joel

results.content:
This course takes you through the entire development of a WordPress plugin from inception to upload and even explains how to handle plugin updates.

Speaking specifically on the WordPress Plugin API, you will create and use Hooks (both Actions and Filters) and Shortcodes frequently throughout the course.

Handling form submission with AJAX, creating and saving your own WordPress options, database manipulation, sending emails with WordPress and procedurally creating admin pages/menus are just some of the things you learn in the course. You can take a look at the full curriculum for specifics but in brief: the volume of information makes for great value.

Joel is well spoken and thoroughly explains the code. He is active in the discussions and frequently exceeds my expectations when it comes to answering a question. He knows his stuff.

Updates/Edits to the course are made regularly (with the help of students) and substantially improve the accuracy of the information presented.

As for production quality, simply see one of the Preview videos.

The course does require a knowledge of PHP and knowledge of SQL also doesn't hurt. I went into this course knowing nothing about WordPress development. Having visited the documentation I know I still have plenty to learn but I now have a better handle on how to use that information.

If you want to learn to build WordPress plugins this is an excellent first choice.

This course is proving invaluable as a companion resource while creating my own plugin.

results.content:
The course achieves it's objectives of teaching you the workings of a wordpress plugin. It gives you everything that you need to know to get going and build your own. That is why I purchased it so I have to say that it gave me value for money.

I have been using php for a very long time (1999). For me, I got what I needed from the course quickly and then skim watched the rest of it. From my perspective the course is probably twice as long as it needs to be and I found myself getting frustrated at just how much time was spent explaining pretty much every line of the php code, even when something almost identical had been explained in an earlier lesson. Time was also spent explaining how some fairly simply php constructs work. 

If you are a less experienced developer I can see how this would be invaluable. If like me you just want to learn how to create a plugin in the shortest possible time then you may too find yourself skimming over the later lessons.

response.content: Thanks for the review and the constructive feedback Tony! I can understand your frustration having my course hold your hand, especially if you're an experienced developer. With this course I tried to make it so that new AND experienced developers could both appreciate the course. Maybe in the future I could provide fast track lessons that with less hand holding and the option to skip past other lessons and still understand the material. Overall, I really appreciate the feedback. I'd really appreciate it if you'd reconsider a star rating that would reflect the experience you think majority of students who might take this course will have, if not I understand. Happy coding friend!

response.content:
Hi Amjad,

Thanks for your honest opinion on the course. I'm sorry that you did not enjoy my teaching style.

I can assure you that I did write all the code for this course myself. The copy/paste method I use in this course is a deliberate choice in order to save my students from hours of watching me type code. Instead, I've chosen to paste small portions of my code and walk my students through a detailed explanation of each line as I do so. This way I avoid making unintentional typos during the video recording and my students can decide if they need to pause or slow down the video for their unique learning style. 

I hope this helps you better understand my teaching choice and perhaps you would reconsider your initial review of this course. 

Happy coding friend!

Joel

The course is inconsistent. Different code editors, mixed and confusing code files, lot's of commenting, extreme use of copy and pasting. The instructor keeps pasting code with functions that do not exist yet with no back and forth to view the results soon enough.

Another thing that does not feel right is the dependency from third party plugins. I would rather be presented with a smaller plugin that is making use of the basic instead of injecting ACF to do the heavy lifting for admin fields. The course is more of a "Copy along" rather than "Code along". Even though the instructor explains what is going on on the pasted code (to save us some time I guess), he is wasting too much time to write comments and talk about references. It is hard to follow along.

The overall feeling is like a developer colleague goes through a plugin he/she created. Uninspiring, I could not finish the course.

results.content:
The course is very instructive and contains a massive amount of valuable information that covers a significant amount Wordpress Plugin Development. With that being said, I could not easily learn from this course. 

Instead of structuring the lessons to go over a wide area of plugin development, they focus specifically on creating individual parts of one massive plugin. Although this structure may be sufficient, I found myself getting lost in a lot of advanced concepts that I may have understood had they have been applied in smaller and simpler plugins. The plugin became very large and when problems occurred, it felt near impossible to determine what went wrong. Furthermore, a lot of the lessons (or parts of lessons) were taught by the instructor "copying and pasting" code and then explaining each part of said code. This style of teaching may be efficient for some, but for me it felt lazy and disengaging. 

Overall, this course provides a massive amount of information and is taught with great excitement, but at the end of the day, I struggled to grasp what was demonstrated.

results.content:
I tried learning WordPress for years by various methods (books, video tutorials) only to fail miserably until I found Brad’s awesome course, Bootstrap to WordPress which finally set me in the right track. And lucky for me, this course was released as soon as I finished that one. It was great timing because I was looking to move into more advance WordPress topics.

Ultimate WordPress Plugin Course indeed a fantastic course. 

Good stuff:

- I learned a lot on what goes into developing plugins and how they’re structured. Like usage of various hooks, shortcodes, filters and interacting with the WP database.
- Learned about integrating other plugins with our own plugin, using frameworks like jQuery to do certain tasks.
- The complete workflow. From laying out the basic directory structure to submitting the plugin to WP plugin directory.
- Joel is an energetic instructor. And he’s actively involved in the discussions answering questions and updating/adding content to the course.

Things that can be improved:

- Personally I’m not a big fan of copying and pasting big chunks of code and going over them method. I prefer the instructor coding alongside me as I tend to understand more what really happens in the code. Another plus point is it reduces room for error on students part because it’s easy to mistype something or miss something while copying lots of code at once. Also in certain lectures,
- More explaining as to why you write something (why pass this value as this parameter etc) instead simply reading the code.
- More preparedness. I felt like the instructor wasn’t prepared beforehand as he kept deleting/re-adding pieces of code which made me a little confused. 
- Some more attention to editing the video afterwards would be good since I noticed in a couple of lectures, the discussed code is out of the view. 

But I wouldn’t hold these against since this course is fairly new and good thing is Joel is actively improving the course so in time, these mistakes will be gone and the course will be more polished.

If you’re a beginner to WordPress or PHP as a whole, this course might not be for you. But if you have your WordPress and PHP basics down, you won’t have any trouble following along. Overall, it’s the best course I’ve done on WordPress plugins for sure.

results.content:
I am a full stack developer,
I was tasked by my company late last year (october with a full release in January) to solve some issues and add features to an existing production Wordpress site. 
With this course I was able to get a good enough understanding of Wordpress plugin development, that i was able to create my own custom plugin that ended up replaced existing event management software. Now multiple departments use the backend admin everyday, and customers use my front end form. 
Only suggestion for Joel, is i wish he included  how to accept client submitted images from a client side form submission, and associate that image with the new post. That took me several days before i built a solution. Joel also teaches how to set  up automatic emails, that was a huge start for me
 when creating my own, email notification system. Thanks Joel for a great starting foundation. I hope you do more videos!!

response.content:
Hi Marian,

Sorry to hear did not enjoy the course so far. As this was my first dive into developing an online course there were some decisions made earlier in the course creation process that could have been improved. In order to hopefully avoid typos and other unnecessary errors in the code I developed a source project in advance and then sometimes pasted this code into the project as we went along. This reduces lecture times but to some students may sometimes feel less engaging and might have students pause lectures more than they'd like to. A lot of students enjoy this lecture style but I understand it's not everyone's cup of tea. All that to say, I appreciate you giving the course a shot and there's no hard feelings if you'd like to request a refund.

Happy coding friend!

~ Joel

results.content:
So far everything is entirely clear and no step is skipped. There doesn't appear to be an assumption that there is previous knowledge. Anyone who can handle the basics of a computer and uses internet can use this tutorial. I wonder how it will be further into the course.

Edit 1: Now going into Lecture 22, I've ran into some issues from Lecture 19 and further. First of all, some of the code doesn't result in the same results Joel shows. I wonder if this is due to updates in PHP/JavaScript or browsers? I'm not sure at all.
Also the Javascript we've added in Lecture 21 doesn't work whatsoever. So that's definitely a big downer.
I do have to say it's a lot of stuff being covered in a small period of time and I probably need to rewatch everything to actually make sense of it all.
I'm just going through it, hoping a lot of it sticks, rather on a subconscious level and musclememory. But there is definitely not enough in-depth explanation why certain things work a certain way. It's rather a "do this and you get that approach", which is awesome if you only come for direct results. (But in that case I might just as well google stuff and hope stackoverflow or documentation has the answers)
I think if you make a course you should always keep in mind any knowledge some people might be lacking. Sadly I can't say I understand everything I write along the course. More of it I actually don't understand.

In terms of commenting this course is superb and something I can take with me with any programming in the future.  We're writing some beautiful code along the course. Even though I don't understand a lot of it, I can clearly tell this is proper looking code. I'm also learning a lot about various ways to do things.

results.content:
Joel is a decent guy! And he is really engaging, supportive and responsive on this course. I appreciated the fact that he replied back on all my questions. He is also doing a good job on delivering what he knows with his way of doing things. 

However, this course might be better labeled as an introduction to a bit more advanced use of Wordpress, mostly as practicing for WP Designers, Marketers or Entrepreneurs who have already the basic knowledge of the standard Web technologies like html, js and php, to help them get more familiar with writing some code inside the WP platform and to gain confidence using all these. It can be considered as the next step, or a good exercise for an advanced WP user, but it should not be the final point of reference for someone who really wants to learn best practices and how to code with high quality standards. 

In my opinion this is not a course for PHP or "Wordpress" developers, as it will not make them better Coders or WP plugin developers, apart of the basic familiarity with WP as described above.

I have to admit that after a point and later I had to skip a lot of the lessons, as I was not getting more knowledge or new things. Some of the other issues with this course are mentioned by other students' comments. 

I also want to suggest that even for this kind of course, there could be a few things done better:
 - a plan of what we do and why
 - deeper explanations on the topics covered
 - a few more tips (e.g. debugging)
 - usage of better practices (e.g. writing secure code)
 - more "real-time trial, error and fix", instead of pasting a bunch of functions and wait too long to see how these finally work.
 - less focus on adding more features for the plugin that got us in writing, and writing custom simple php things, and more focus on using WP API stuff.

Still, I appreciate Joel's efforts and everything this course had to offer and really hope my review will help Joel improve both in terms of creating his courses, or even becoming a better WP plugin developer.

And finally, did I say that Joel is a decent guy?

response.content: During this course I teach you how to dramatically speed up development by leveraging two (not three) plugins designed specifically for WordPress plugin development: Custom Post Types UI and Advanced Custom Fields. However, your completed plugin DOES NOT REQUIRE THESE PLUGINS TO BE INSTALLED in order to work and I teach this in the course. Custom Post Types UI is a shortcut to generating the PHP code for WordPress's built in register_post_type() function. Later in the course we include this PHP in our own file and no longer need CPTUI. Advanced Custom Fields is a library of functions that makes it easier to create custom fields and save post meta data. Additional lectures are coming to this course soon teaching the fully manual way of doing this as well. This plugin is specifically designed to be included in plugin code to speed up development time, and all this is taught in the course. Please consider updating your review when you have completed the course material.

results.content: This was an amazingly detailed course that taught me a lot about the inner workings of WordPress.  I developed this plugin with WordPress 5.0.3 and PHP 7.2 and everything worked fine.  There were a few spots where I had to search the Q&A to answer a question but I always found someone else who had the same issue and I got my questions resolved.  One note is that I never did get outgoing mail working in my localhost wordpress environment.  However that wasn't a problem because I deployed it to a live server and got mail working with an SMTP plugin.  Apparently Google has gotten stricter on using their server for outgoing mail from an application.  So I had to jump through some hoops to register my application with Google to get it to work.  Great course!  Highly recommended!

Really like that we are building a working plugin and adding features. I would recommend 2 things so far.
1. For tasks that require detailed steps in Wordpress like installing and setting up CPT, list them in a text file somewhere since they are not provided in your resources outside of the video.
2. Use wp_localize_script to set a javascript variable to pass script url's and actions instead of hard coding in the js. You should also consider accounting for sites that are not at the root level. Your code does not work in this case.
I added this to myslb_public_scripts()
// get base url - helps if site is not at root
$url = site_url('/wp-admin/');
wp_localize_script( 'my-snappy-list-builder-js-public', 'AjaxVars', array(
'postId' => $post->ID,
'action_register' => 'myslb_save_subscription',
'action_unsubscribe' => 'myslb_unsubscribe',
'url' => $url . 'admin-ajax.php'
));
And then I can use AjaxVars.action_register and AjaxVars.url in jQuery.

Also, I was having trouble using your nonce code. You were generating a nonce and it was in the form, but you were only verifying the referrer url? I am using a function to verify the nonce itself that was registered. I am sure you know this already.
// verify nonce
$nonce = $_POST['_wpnonce'];
if(wp_verify_nonce( $nonce, 'myslb-register-subscription_'.$list_id )):

Maybe consider a rewrite into a class mvc style project? I would pay to watch that.

results.content:
This seems to be the only popular WordPress plugin course on Udemy. It's pretty decent. I particularly enjoyed the final sections about distributing and selling plugins. I wish he would have gone into even more detail and listed more options for how to distribute plugins.

I liked most things about the course except the code organization. While it's nice that Joel uses a table of contents to organize his code, the functions themselves seem all over the place. There are some functions that do a lot of work that could easily be split into more functions. There are some functions that do next to nothing that shouldn't have been their own functions. Part of that is because WordPress forces you into a lot of decisions. While Joel goes into what some of those decisions are early on by explaining things like actions, filters, and shortcodes, a little more description may have helped. Perhaps a more high-level diagram or flowchart explaining how plugins flow through WordPress. I think Joel's code could have benefitted greatly from some object-orientation as well. One of the strengths of object-oriented code is the organization benefits. All this being said, this is a great course. The plugin Joel creates has a lot of interesting functionality. Data manipulation, custom database tables, email, import/export, admin pages, etc. Thank you Joel.

response.content:

There are a lot of great suggestions here. I'm working on new course material that utilizes an object-oriented approach so this is confirmation that this is a good direction to go. I also love your suggestions for high-level diagrams and will work to incorporate those into future updates.

Thanks again for the excellent review!

Joel

Joel

results.content: Overall it was a good course but about 1/3 in we went from explaining the lines of code being added into cut-and-paste with brief explanations. I think what gets left out there is the concept that the course teaches overall, building the program in layers starting from the basic foundation. In this class it was an email subscribe function but if student wants to do something else, would be nice to cover additional abstract concepts such as how to build a good program infrastructure before starting to code. What are good naming conventions, etc... Also, was said to see no lesson on how to offer a pro-version (paid) of a plugin within the free version that is made available for public download. How does one do an effective license number code to valida/invalidate the pro version, how do you combat piracy of your plugin if you just sell it, etc... This is a big piece and it's missing for monetization. Overall, lots of ground covered. Good course, worth the investment. Highly recommend.

Another example would be Settings API. Diving right into it, without proper familiarization.

results.content:
I've previously completed PHP and WordPress theme development courses (beginner level), so this is well positioned for me to take the next step. Really like the style and pace of Joel's course.

But be aware that there is a significant amount of coding to be done. Whilst it is clear and well structured code, if like me you don't know jQuery and are a bit hazy on AJAX some of it will be black magic. 

My suggestion to Joel would be perhaps to spend a little more time on the key concepts before some of the big modules.
